elements.title: Ludovic Antal (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 1968, actor Ludovic Antal (pictured) recited a Romanian nationalist poem in front of tourists from Soviet Moldavia, causing them to flee for their bus for fear of a "provocation"?

elements.title: a public TV station in Texas (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a public TV station in Texas held an eight-hour telethon before it even began broadcasting?

elements.title: Lauk Shein (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Governor Lauk Shein of Bassein fled the city along with "ten elephant loads of gold and silver", but could not outrun the pursuing Hanthawaddy troops?

elements.title: C/1990 K1 (Levy) (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that C/1990 K1 (Levy) was the first comet observed by the Hubble Space Telescope, but only short exposures were obtained as the telescope was not yet able to track Solar System bodies?

elements.title: Nicholas Russo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the pastor of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral made Nicholas Russo celebrate Mass in the basement of the church because Russo was Italian?

elements.title: Spear (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Nicola Griffith's novella Spear examines how the Roman conquest made Britain an ethnically diverse society?

elements.title: Charlie Gray (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Major League Baseball pitcher Charlie Gray was billed as his team's pitcher "of six fingers and six toed fame" and called "a freak" by the Sporting Life?

elements.title: Dunning–Kruger club (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that "the first rule of the Dunning–Kruger club is you don't know you're a member of the Dunning–Kruger club"?
